Title:
Studies on some gall bladder myxosporeans (Myxozoa):
prevalence, genetic distances, cryptic species assemblages and
development of multiplex PCR
Keywords:
Chloromyxum; Zschokkella; cyprinid fishes; multiplex PCR;
cryptic species; ribosomal DNA; prevalence
Abstract:
Chloromyxum cristatum, C. fluviatile, and Zschokkella nova
(Myxozoa: Myxosporea) are common gall bladder parasites of cyprinid
fishes where they frequently occur in mixed infections. Light and
scanning electron microscopy were used for the morphological
characterization of these myxosporeans. Especially, the latter method
was essential for the identification of C. cristatum and C. fluviatile
whose spores are known for the high variability in their complex surface
pattern. The prevalence of C. cristatum, C. fluviatile, and Z. nova in
the samples of Hypophthalmichthys molitrix and Ctenopharyngodon idella
is assessed. The phylogenetic position of these parasites is retrieved
from the SSU and LSU rDNA data and compared to the known phylogeny of C.
cyprini and C. legeri, junior synonyms of C. cristatum and C.
fluviatile. Intra- and interspecies variability is studied by the
comparison of myxosporean genetic distances. Specific PCR primers
targeting the D2 region of LSU rDNA of these species were designed. The
comparison of the detection efficiency of the light microscopy, standard
PCR and multiplex PCR has shown that the last method is the most
effective tool for the detection of these myxosporeans and their
discrimination when present in mixed infections. The synonymy of C.
cyprini with C. cristatum is supported by our molecular data and the
existence of cryptic species assemblages of C. fluviatile and Z. nova is
suggested. However, these findings have to be confirmed by further
molecular studies on well morphologically characterized isolates of
these myxosporeans from their type hosts.
